candidates.title: create a new hc command to run a holochain webrtc signal server
candidates.body:
### Summary

Adds a new `hc signal-srv` command to run a local holochain webrtc signal server that can be passed into a command like `hc sandbox generate network webrtc ws://127.0.0.1:xxx`.

candidates.title: Backport feature consistency for sqlite
candidates.body:
### Summary

I've really tried to minimise the possibility of a break here. I think that the `hdi` and the `hdk` will behave the same as they did which is the main thing. People *may* have problems building `holochain` with a partial upgrade of its dependencies but I'm struggling to construct a problem scenario in my head.

I do think this would be worse testing with a pre-release version before it goes into `0.1.5` though

### TODO:

candidates.title: Feature consistency for sqlite
candidates.body:
### Summary

~~This has the potentail to break things, for now it's just demonstrating the changes that are needed to make sure that when building this repo, sqlite is only built one way and is never linked to a system dependency~~

Consuming `hdi`/`hdk` should not change, the database should never be imported or built. Everywhere else you have to choose between `no-deps` to enable sqlite with bundling or `db-encryption` which bundles sqlite with encryption enabled. I've tried not to change any defaults for other binaries, e.g. `hc_sandbox` builds without encryption always and `holochain` builds without encryption when built with default features.

I'd still like to come back to this and see if any dependency paths to `rusqlite` can be removed. But for now, this PR should just be expressing what we already meant to do - just more explicitly which helps avoid build/linker issues when enabling `resolver = "2"`

candidates.title: remove tx2 configs + delete kitsune direct
candidates.body:
### Summary

- BREAKING CHANGE - Removes conductor networking types "Proxy" ("proxy") and "Quic" ("quic"). Please transition to "WebRTC" ("webrtc").
- Deletes kitsune_direct testing framework, which was largely built around tx2, and awkwardly mocked out holochain, making it difficult to maintain. Please transition to using sweettest for network integration testing.

NOTE: this just comments out the configs, leaving open an easy revert in the tiny chance case that webrtc is not ready. We will need a follow-on PR to actually remove the tx2 code once we're sure we won't be going back.

### TODO:

candidates.title: Integrate ability to "close" tx5 "connections"
candidates.body:
integrate https://github.com/holochain/tx5/pull/25:

Since tx5 endpoints work as a message queue, opening / retrying connections as needed under the hood, there isn't a direct analog for "Closing" a connection. Yet, holochain still needs this ability if we don't want to speak to a remote node.

This PR introduces the concept of a remote id "ban" where we won't send messages to, accept messages from, or allow connections to a particular remote id for a specified time length. We can consider / configure the length of this ban period in the holochain integration PR, but perhaps ~10 seconds would function as a starting point, since, if they try to re-establish a connection after that time period, we will simply ban them again.

candidates.title: enabling native ios, pre-conditions
candidates.body: ### Summary `hc pack` takes `--dylib-ios` in order that it should emit some `.dylib` files, and that the yaml/manifest should contain references to the files. The reason this is necessary is that to build for iOS and to ship your app, no [JIT-compiled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Just-in-time_compilation) code is allowed, which is the default way that holochain+wasmer handle the wasm DNA code. With .dylib files, those native ios instructions can be codesigned and thus not a security vulnerability for iOS - [x] gives holochain the native ability to handle WasmDylibZome type zomes in addition to standard WasmZome. - [x] very fast wasm instruction execution time because there's no compile step during runtime - [x] minor refactor to consolidate wasmer related code Could be extended in the future for MacOS affordances and performance improvements. I don't believe that Android will need to make use of this, due to lesser security controls. Apple briefly experimented with allowing JIT in some beta versions of iOS, but subsequently disabled it again prior to release. (https://twitter.com/altstoreio/status/1354096048650809349). ### TODO: - [ ] CHANGELOG(s) updated with appropriate info - [ ] Just before pressing the merge button, ensure new entries to CHANGELOG(s) are still under the _UNRELEASED_ heading ### How it works 1. Use this in your build DNA command, note the --ios-serialize: hc dna pack --dylib-ios --output=happ/workdir/projects.dna happ/workdir/dna/projects When you run it, this will produce some additional files. You will need to add these to your iOS app project folder, and include those files in the final build of your iOS app. 2. Add lines in your dna.yaml file to each zome specifying where the wasm dylib file will be, relative to your IOS ROOT SOURCE FOLDER

candidates.title: feat/extend-network-info-with-data-about-peers
candidates.body:
### Summary

Indicators of peer network size and activity should be available for the Launcher and other apps to display. This PR extends the existing App API call `NetworkInfo` with several such data points.

I couldn't think of a way to test different scenarios like arc sizes or completed gossip rounds without using > 120 conductors. Mocking the DB would have been ideal I believe.
